awd_titl_txt: SuSCheM: Environmentally Sustainable Pathways for Extracting Valuable Elements from Electronic Wastes
awd_abstract_narration:
1706905 (Park). E-waste (e.g., cell phones and PCs), which is the fastest growing waste segment in the United States, is emerging as a major environmental challenge in today's society. A novel approach to reclaim valuable components such as metals and chemicals from existing products and wastes, also known as urban mining, is essential for the sustainable treatment of e-waste. By recovering metals and chemicals from waste streams with integrated material looping cycles, a number of benefits can be accrued: environmental sustainability achieved via the reuse of metals and chemicals, reduced need for natural ores, reduced environmental contamination, and energy savings for metal extraction (10-15% less energy is needed for metal recovery from e-waste than ores), and reduced health hazards from direct disposal of those wastes. The integrated e-waste treatment scheme to be created by this project involves the systematic elemental mapping and characterization of e-wastes, chemically enhanced leaching of metals using innovative ligand systems and safer solvents, and tailored precipitation and electrowinning of metals. Finally, the overall environmental impact of the proposed technology will be investigated via a comprehensive life cycle analysis.

The ultimate goal of the present three-year study is to establish an innovative, integrated, environmentally sustainable e-waste processing scheme that allows for the efficient treatment and recovery of metals and chemicals from e-waste. If successful, the proposed technology will significantly reduce the landfilling of e-wastes, the emissions from hazardous halogenated flame retardant plastics, and the need for toxic chemicals, while allowing for enhanced recovery of valuable materials from e-waste. The fundamental understanding obtained from this study will provide important insights into other material/waste recycle schemes involving complex chemistry and structures. As an integral part of the project, the team's educational and outreach activities are inseparably linked to the research plan. The four main goals in this effort include: to promote the international research and educational collaborations in the proposed research area; to motivate K-12 students, particularly female and minority students, to pursue a career in science and engineering; to provide academic research experience for both graduate and undergraduate students; and to enable the development of a new curriculum reflecting an increasing interest in green energy and environmental issues. To achieve these goals, the PIs have planned specific programs including: (a) K-12 outreach via a new kids' journal called Frontiers for Young Minds where kids from 8 to 15 will be engaged in scientific journal publication by serving as reviewers; and, (b) the development of MOOC Masters program on energy and material sustainability to be hosted at multi-institutions in USA, Europe, China and Korea.

por.por_cntn:
Mining is one of the most energy-intensive industries and its conventional exploration and processing processes emit large amounts of pollutants. Thus, in order to reduce the environmental footprint of our materials cycle for a sustainable future, it is important to develop a circular economy of elements. In this study, we propose waste electrical and electronic equipment (WEEE) as an excellent resource for urban mining. WEEE is one of the fastest growing waste industries with serious environmental concerns. Unfortunately, the chemistry of metal recovery from WEEE is toxic and hazardous. Here, we investigated supercritical CO2 (scCO2) as a greener co-solvent to improve the environmental sustainability of the urban mining technology. There were a few studies using scCO2 to degrade polymers or extract Br from WEEE. However, the main mechanisms of chemical interactions between scCO2 and WEEE are still poorly understood. 

Thus, in this project we developed two-step reaction scheme: (1) pre-treatment using scCO2/acid solvent and (2) hydrometallurgical process using acid/oxidant, to mechanistically investigate the physical and chemical changes of electronic wastes. Our study suggested that scCO2 creates large porosity during the pre-treatment step via dissolving Ca-silicate-bearing fiberglass, and this accelerates the degradation of polymer matrix of the electronic wastes and enhance the subsequent metal extraction. The mapping of the cross-sectional areas has provided direct evidence of the fate of elements (i.e., Cu, Au, Ca, Si) during the treatment of electronic wastes. The findings from this study are not only important for the environmentally-friendly design of electronic waste treatment technologies, but also for the understanding of leaching behaviors of complex layered structures (e.g., electronic parts) in different solvent systems. 

 

Intellectual Merit – This project achieved fast and selective recovery of various metals (i.e. Cu, Ni, Au) from electronic wastes. This project is the first study providing unique mechanisms of CO2 interaction with complex electronic materials with layered structures and the leaching behaviors of metals. The findings from this study can provide valuable insights into how greener technologies could potentially enhance the sustainable recovery of metals from WEEE.

 

Broader Impact - As an integral part of this project, the team promoted the international research and educational collaborations in the area of urban mining and waste and CO2 utilization via workshops attended by invited experts in various fields and student exchange efforts. We also worked with K-12, undergraduate and masters students, particularly female and minority students. They are now pursuing their careers in science and engineering and many of them are continuing their education in graduate schools.
